Review Contents: I purchased these from a Seller in HK through ebay. Paid more for this. I already have the Urbanite Xl, bluetooth. These have a very similar sound signature as the Urbanites.Here are things I liked about it1) APT-X no lag when watching movies / playing games.2) Very good sound. I have the HD 600 that I use at home for music. This sounds just as clear as them. I have a lossless track of Katie Melua & Eva Cassidy singing What a wonderful world. Most headphones tend to muddy the voices to the point where you are guessing who is singing what. Not this one, you can clearly make out the difference between the two through these.3) These headphones are much brighter than the HD 600's, they have a foot tapping liveliness that is easy to love.4) Bass extension, the bass guitar riffs sound real on these to my untrained ears. Close enough to the real thing, (I play the bass). Listening to a track like Carousel by Melanie Martinez, where other bass heavy headphones like Beats Studio starts to distort, this plays with authority and clarity. These are no where near as bass heavy as most other gen - next headphones out there, but they are not bass shy either. When they do play bass, they do it well.5) I flew to Ireland and got stuck in a long lay over situation. The net duration was 28 hours including layover. This paired with a tablet, lasted me the entire time. I had to charge the Tablet 5 times during the trip, this one was still going strong when I finally switched off. The LiPo batteries are awesome.What I dont like1) These are on ear for me. I admit I am 6'1 and have elephant ears. Still I have no idea why Sennheiser cant build a HD 600 sized bluetooth headphone ?I purchased the Brainwavez hybrid headphone pads and they fit right and go over the ears, but that needed some electrical tape to happen and killed the looks of the headphone.I have this exact same issue with my Urbanite XL as well. Its more like an Urbanite M, not XL.2) Bluetooth range its good enough for 15-20 feet, LOS, after that it cuts out. It most likely will not be a problem for anyone, but my $ 15 kinivo bluetooth headphones from Amazon has 3x the range, not sure why sennheiser cant do this ? This is not a deal breaker for me, but it bothered me that a $ 15 headphone can beat this in range.3) The headband doesnt have any real cushioning to it. Its better than urbanite but barely so. After a few hours of extended listening, the top of my head starts to hurt. I fixed this with an add on pad, but that makes this look really bad.4) The noise cancelling is a an experiment in compromise, I think its set at a mid point between complete isolation and zero noise cancelling. I think that is because complete isolation causes some people to have a perceived headache/ear ache. I have spent hours in the shooting range for the Marines before and I have used the BHP, (Ballistic Hearing Protection). They are really foam based ear plugs with a fancy name. Anyway, zero ambient noise does not bother me.So for guys like me, I wish there was a more aggressive noise cancellation. Maybe a three level adjustable noise cancellation with the final level set aggressively.At +/- $150.00, these are great. But if noise cancellation is the only thing you need and sound quality is as important to you as the current drought in Nigeria, I would recommend the Bose headphones. Otherwise, these are quite awesome and slightly better sounding than the Urbanite XL.
Title: Great but not for large ears

Review Contents: When these were announced at CES (2017) I was really excited. I had been contemplating taking the dive and buying significantly higher quality headphones than the cheapo ones I usually tend to buy. I figured these would be a decent compromise between the expensive $350+ headphones that dominate the "best" Bluetooth with active noise cancellation that you can buy and the extremely cheapo sub-$100 Bluetooth headphones. They took a good 3 weeks or so to ship, but that will likely improve when there is more stock readily available.First thoughts were that the packaging was very well done and Amazon also did a good job of choosing a box with filler that didn't allow it to shift all over the place. Inside the packaging it is bare-bones, just the headphones, cable, cheap bag carrying case, and some leaflets. While they are plastic, they did not feel cheap. Obviously that is an opinion and I think that quality plastic can be great in some scenarios, just like metal can be in other scenarios... So your mileage may vary.I paired these up with a OnePlus 3 (no aptX) and oh boy, what sound. Honestly, listening to music on these was a revelation much like the first time I hooked up a surround sound system to my TV. Coming from cheap headphones that "work" you don't realize how much you are missing from the music you listen too. The sound is super crisp and vibrant. I could hear extra detail from the instruments that I didn't before on much cheaper Bluetooth headphones. I feel like the bass was there, but not overbearing. I am not a bass head, so people wanting super saturated base probably should look elsewhere, in my opinion.Now for the bad. I have a big head. I am the sort of person that dies a little inside when you look at a hat and it says "one size fits all". Liars. haha. I ought to have listened to some of the other reviews that I had read stating these were not rainbows and butterflies on large heads. The biggest issue are the size of the ear cups. For anyone with adult sized ears these will likely be closer to ON ear as opposed to OVER ear. The material is nice and soft (a faux leather of some sort), but with it all on my ears, it got roasty pretty quick. On that same vein, I feel like because of the size of my head, they didn't quite fit comfortably and would get a little uncomfortable on the top of my head and to a lesser degree my ears after wearing them for a while.I will be honest, I did not test the Active Noise Cancellation (ANC) much. It seemed like they did a decent job killing general ambient noise, but I don't really have anything to compare them against as a reference for "WOW these are amazing" levels of ANC. Honestly, for half the cost of the "Golden Standard" of ANC (Bose QC35) you can't expect it to be earthshattering. I will say that the "white-noise" that some older ANC headsets has is virtually non-existent, which is nice.I don't want to discourage people with smaller heads from these. The sound you get is awesome and you get the bonus of great battery life and ANC in an exceptionally reasonable price. I would give it 3.5 stars if I could, but I want to be sure that people with bigger heads think twice before they buy these. Maybe I just have a sensitive large head and other people wouldn't find my qualms an issue, but I want to put out the word regardless. I ended up returning them and am back to researching a decent set of headphones that won't cost me a kidney, but will cover my big head and ears.TLDR:Pros+ Quality plastic construction (yes, plastic and quality can be in the same sentence)+ Great sound, super crisp and vibrant, bass not overbearing+ No sound bleed (at volume levels that won't make you deaf)+ Great battery lifeCons- Marketed as OVER ear, really actually ON ear- Uncomfortable on larger sized heads- Ear cups, though comfortable, warm up quickly as they are on your ear (not over)Other thoughts* Active Noise Cancellation is nice, but not phenomenal* Price to sound and build quality ratio is great* If your head isn't huge... these are definitely worth looking into* If your head is huge... you probably want to look elsewhere
Title: Great sound, but bad for big heads and ears

Review Contents: I like Sennheiser. I've always had a good experience with their products ever since my first "real" set of quality headphones, the PC151 for my computer ~15 years ago.But this was the first time I've used their bluetooth headphones, and also the first time I've used their ANC. I take the train to and from work each day, and mostly wanted a pair of BT headphones that block out the noise both from the train and also from the people around me. These do that and then some. Despite what others may say, these headphones completely block out all of the noise from the train and let me enjoy my commute in peace. The sound quality is great considering my current phone does not support aptX, and I can't complain at all about the comfort or fit. Maybe I just have small ears? Regardless, this is a great product. I've used the Bose and Sony models, and they're also very quality products, but I really enjoy these headphones.The battery life surprised me. I'm coming from a set of Sony BT headphones without ANC. They'd last a good month or two between charges. I expected to take a hit in the battery life department, but I've managed to go ~3 weeks before hearing the low battery message, using them 4-5 days a week for 1-2 hours a day. Really can't complain with battery life like that.The ANC isn't perfect, though. I can still hear some noises, but with music playing it's a non-issue. Not enough for me to subtract a star, anyway. And even with no music playing, it completely silences the train. I hear a "snap" or "pop" sound when the ANC kicks in, then it's all quiet.If you're looking for good quality noise-cancelling headphones and don't want to pay $350-400, this is your best bet.
Title: Sennheiser always delivers

Review Contents: It's really funny because the only negative reviews are "this headphone is too small" or "it's an on the ear not an over the ear headphone".  I'm 6'4" with a pretty large head and appropriately sized ears for my head, and I can manage them just fine.  Unless you have Mad Magazine cartoonishly large ears you should be fine.  It's definitely not a loose fit, but it's not uncomfortable, and I can wear them for hours without issue.The other negative I see is someone said that "the noise cancelling is too hard to activate".  To turn the noise cancelling on, you have to press the up and down volume at the same time and hold for like 1 second.  It's a single rocker, and the mediocre pictogram does show them using two fingers.  PERSONALLY, I use just my thumb and I manage fine...Anyway, outside of stupid people leaving bad reviews.  The sound profile is pretty good on bluetooth.  It's only atpX, not aptX HD, so you get 16 bit audio out of it so approximately CD quality.  That's still enough to tell that any audio from YouTube is "meh" at best, and that other websites have better bitrates.  The nice thing is that you can plug it in and listen wired if you want to and it does come with a 2.5mm to 3.5mm cable so you can plug your headset into any normal aux port.  They sound WAY better plugged in as long as your machine can output 24 bit audio (which makes sense if you think about it).The sound profile is nice and fairly clean, mids are a touch muddy, but the bass response is really nice.  Treble COULD be a bit punchier for my taste, but it's pretty clean and I haven't heard any clipping in the 10-ish hours I've used them to listen to music.  Basically, they are not studio quality headphones, what they are is really good quality general purpose headphones with a great name, good frequency response, and nice convenience being both bluetooth and wired.  I would highly recommend them if you're looking for what I'm describing above, if you're looking for more audiophile/studio/sit at home in a butterfly chair with a pipe listening to ELO on vinyl headphones at about the same price, the Audio Technica ath-m50x are about the same price including a bluetooth adapter.
Title: Great value for price general purpose noise cancelling headphones.

Review Contents: Sound: close to neutral and very clear, highly detailed, with a gentle touch of bass.These headphones are meant for advanced listeners and audiophiles seeking to customize their own sound preference using an equalizer (and have the proper app/hardware to do so). Sennheiser do not over manipulate frequencies, so the headphones may not have the out-of-the-box 'wow' effect most buyers are looking for.The mids are indeed strong as some say, and my guess is that it was done to achieve more gain or volume. This feature can be adjusted.Overall, a very detailed and stunning sound experience, once shaped to your taste. These headphones shine when listening to the mellow sounds of Radiohead, the powerful beats of Polica and the warmth of Bon Iver.Sennheiser's app, CapTune, can help you find the right EQ to match your sound taste.I personally use PowerAmp for android. Added screen caps of my personal EQ settings (with ANC turned off and on).ANC: Very (very) basic noise reduction for this price range. Cuts off low-frequency noise only, but it's better than nothing. It will not mute voices, external music and you will not feel isolated from the world.Build: Perfect. It's Sennheiser.
Title: HD 4.50 sound review + EQ settings

Review Contents: I am Sennheisers biggest fan.  I absolutely fell in love with their products based on sound quality and value.  I have always preferred the in ear phones and recently bought the 4.5 wireless blue tooth headphones.  At first listen i was very impressed, after listening to them for about a week I noticed the mid ranges literally seems to be overwhelming and the Bass is not as robust.  Almost a tinny sound (which I relate to cheap).  I think I am going to return them, not really happy as I thought I would be.
Title: Great Headphones, but not as good as I anticipated

Review Contents: Super comfy, although someone with larger ears may not find it comfortable. The product came with a little carrying bag (although I bought a carrying case at the same time), which is enough to carry the headphones. The sound quality is excellent! The noise cancelling feature is good as well but some background noise can still be heard.Edit: I almost returned these because I wasn’t able to pair my headphones to my phone. I had contacted both Amazon tech support and Sennheiser support, both responded quickly enough (the latter responded more than a day later) If anyone makes the same mistake as me.... make sure you hold on to the power button while connecting, it’ll flash blue and red, and let go once it’s connected. Don’t be silly like me and just turn the headphones on wondering why my phone couldn’t detect them...Also if you wear glasses it may not be 100% comfy. They jut mine out a little bit even if I try to push my glasses inward.
Title: Super comfy, although someone with larger ears may not ...

Review Contents: I love Sennheiser.  I have owned quite a few of them, even their esoteric HE90. I still have HD650 for my home reference headphone.  When I started looking for a noise cancelling headphones a year ago, I picked Sennheiser Momentum 2 blind.  The ear cup of M2 is too small too shallow, can't wear them even for short period of time.  So I give it away and pick Definitive Technology Symphony 1, which has good sound quality and huge ear cup.The DT Symphony 1 is not perfect -- a bit mid-bass boom, a tad grainy mid-range.  But the biggest problem is the headband: it presses on the top of my head which make it also impossible to wear for too long.  So I started to look for a new pair of  BTNC headphones.  I don't like BOSE brand but I tried the QC35 at BestBuy and their are extremely comfortable!  SONY 1000X is not that comfortable for me and doesn't sound very impressive either.  But I couldn't find any Sennheiser 4.50BTNC at store to try on so I bought them on Amazon and hope Sennheiser has fixed the ear cup design flaw.  Boy was I wrong!  the ear cup is still the same small/shallow design as in M2.  I can't wear them for too long.  Yeah I admit people have different anatomy so maybe mine is a bit off but my ear is certainly on the mid/small side for sure.  I am so disappointed.  I give 4.50BTNC one stars for sound quality which is ok.  but not as expected from Sennheiser.  sound stage is hollow,  frequency response is not balanced. Also the max sound volume is quite low, which could be an issue for some recordings.  As a comparison,  Bose QC35 is better in EVERY aspects!My advise for people consider buying 4.50BTNC:  TRY THEM ON before you buy!  They may work for you but don't assume so.  Also try Bose QC35 if you can!I posted the side-by-side photos of 4.50BTNC, HD650, and BOSE QC35  for reference.
Title: Ear cup too small and uncomfortable

Review Contents: Works fine and the sound quality is good but they really hug your head and there isn't a lot of space in the ear cups. These two things mean that they are uncomfortable to wear for more than a short time and make your ears hot. I don't have a large head. The ear cups are also a cheaper material so they'll probably last a long time but they're fairly stiff.Bottom line: Functionality is good, noise cancellation is good, and I can't really tell the difference between wired and bluetooth. However, comfortable is poor. If you plan to use them around the house for an hour or less, they'll be perfect. If you want these to travel and fly with, look elsewhere.
Title: Works fine and the sound quality is good but they really ...

Review Contents: I gotta say that I am definitely a fan of these headphones, even though I returned them. My ears fit into the cups just fine (despite what others have said), but my wife says I have small ears, so there's that.  The sound quality is very good, especially with electronic music, though I'm sure all genres would hold up.However, I returned them because I didn't find the noise cancellation to be that great.  It definitely works but it only cuts out the lower end of the spectrum, leaving the highs to be acutely heard once the lows are eliminated.  I found that to distracting at times, though admittedly I kind of have OCD.That said, I had a hard time keeping them when I've read that the Bose (QC 35 ii) and Sonys (WH-1000XM2) do much better at noise cancellation.  I finally decided to pull the trigger and get the Bose and I am glad I did.  They are a lot softer and thus more comfortable, and the noise cancellation definitely works better, albeit marginally (they definitely don't block out *all* noise as I have been made to understand by reading reviews, but they eat into higher frequencies than the Sennheisers).  I'd say the price difference in price between them is accurate for what you get, so if you're willing to shell out nearly twice as much for the Bose you definitely get a more comfortable and effective product.Final note: They do sound great, so if that's your primary concern you're golden.  I think the Sennheisers actually sound just as good as the Bose, it was very hard to tell the difference.  Maybe that's just because, again, I was playing electronic music.  It was a short test, I was already sold on the Bose from the moment I put them on so I didn't spend very much time comparing them.
Title: Silver Medal

Review Contents: If you're like me and trying to figure out if these headphones are worth the price, here is my answer: YES. If you're upgrading from anything cheaper, you'll love these. I use these for video editing and with my 2011 iMac, it uses the best quality possible (aptX), with no lag. The noise reduction isn't perfect, but with music playing, it's great. They're comfortable, and the charge the battery holds is beyond expectation. Please buy these!
Title: If you're like me and trying to figure out if these headphones ...

Review Contents: Bought these for my girlfriend to block out all the ruckus I make when playing online with my buddy.  So far she hasn't been able to hear me so that's great.  They are very light and produce high quality audio with a much appreciated basic/sleek design.  We haven't tested the battery life but we haven't had any issues with it.  If you have big ears you might find these cups a bit small and will not sit over your ear completely; I uploaded a picture of them lying next to my Sennheiser HD558 which sits very comfortably over my larger ears. Build quality is good with a smooth quality plastic feel (I mean that in a good way), however, it could use a bit more padding under the band.  The controls on the cup are not intuitive or easy to distinguish; I feel they could have done a better job implementing the controls.  Overall, these are good wireless headphones but I think a price tag closer to $100, instead of $150, would make this a better bargain.
Title: One of the better mid range wireless headphones.

Review Contents: These headphones are not bad, I give them three stars because they are not a good value in my opinion.  For the money you're spending you can truthfully get comparable or better build quality and performance.Build quality - Not bad but not premium either.  They are solid but they do feel plasticy (they are plastic) and cheap, but well put together.  Solid build does count for something but but when cheap materials are used it kinda takes some of that away.Sound - I was not impressed to say the least.  They didn't sound bad but they also didn't sound good.  If I paid $40 for these I would say they sound good (not great) but that is not what you pay and I definitely expected way more.  The volume is also on the low side with both ANC on and off.  Decent sounding headphone but not what I expected in this price range.ANC - NO, my passive noice cancelling headphones (Avantree Auditions) do almost as good of a job blocking out the outside world.  I turned ANC on and off and there wasn't that big of a difference to me.  With just a small fan on, I still heard the fan up until I turned the music up past 50%, you may say that's good but that is the same result I got with my Avantrees and they have no ANC.Comfort was good, the ear cups are very plush and you could wear these for a while.  I like the locking 2.5mm audio cable...I hate yanking those out.  Again I am not saying that these are bad headphones, they are actually good...but for this price, no, you can get similar or better even cheaper. Oddly enough my Avantrees have out-shined  or matched these in all categories and they are 1/3 of the cost.  I only looked to replace them because  they are getting old and the USB port has developed a short.
Title: Good headphones, bad value.

Review Contents: Sound quality and battery life are great.  As others mentioned, ear cups are too small and fitment is a bit tight.  I can deal with it after some adjustment.  If they were in the 300+ range, I would have returned them for a more comfortable pair but given I paid about $175, I'll just hang on to them.  Initial prompt voice has a british accent which is odd for the US market but whatever.
Title: Sound quality/battery is great, comfort/fitment needs work.

Review Contents: Pretty good, OK. They sound great. Sound quality is what you would expect or better from $100 Sennheisers. I cannot discern a difference in audio quality between these and anything else, although they do seem to be a bit on the warm side, they are not overly so. They'll start with 5 stars for this. The First real problem is you can't use them in any way while you charge them. The Bluetooth stuff turns off when the usb is connected for charging. There's a loud hiss when both the USB charging and 3.5mm cables are connected to a source. Sounds kinda like a bad ground loop. It _May_ be this unit only, but everything else works fine (after a few minutes debugging an issue that amazon caused). They can't be 5-star if you can't charge and use them simultaneously.Also, they require a better Bluetooth adapter. https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B009ZIILLI does NOT work, despite being suggested as an add-on by amazon. I do not fault them for this, but rather amazon for selling me incompatible products together in a bundle.Second real problem is when you attempt to use these as a phone headset. It's specifically designed for ths, and even has programed buttons for answer, hangup, voice dial, etc. The only problem is that other people cannot consistently hear you. Your voice cuts out, and they complain.  It's like the microphone isn't able to consistently pick up your voice. Loose another star for not being able to do something they're advertised to do. Luckily it's not what I bought them for, and they do play music well. -1 more star, down to three.Also, as others have said, this isn't for people with larger ears or heads. I can only keep these on for about an hour before my head hurts. I think i'll have to go back to my HD-280 pro's, at least for a few hours a day. some days I wear headphones for 6-7 hours. Yeah, lets go ahead and take another star off for these. It's really not that bad because I HAVE to take them off for conference calls, but still... -1 more star. down to two.These are arguabally supra-aural, not circumaural, as advertised. I guess it depends on your ear sizes, but that's not really a fair comparison. They need to fit around at least 85% of peoples' ears, otherwise they're just supra-aural. minus 1 more star. oh noes! we've reached 1 star.Will be returning these.
Title: I really want to love these... but cannot.

Review Contents: These are great headphones!  I love that they fold up small and portable.  They are very comfotable, and the active noise cancelling is decent.  They have a nice built in mic and the control buttons to control playback are the best I've ever seen on headphones or earbuds.  They are made of nice materials and feel sturdy, and they are a little heavy.  They have an INCREDIBLE battery life.  They come with soft carrying pouch and a charger and an AUX cord for wired music.  The sennheiser app is decent.  They have a customizeable EQ, but my one complaint is that the bass is not very powerful.  I wish it was more bassy.  They look cool and they are great headphones! MUCH BETTER THAN Sony XB950B1
Title: Not as much bass as I want there to be, incredible battery life, full, crisp sound, decent ANC

Review Contents: Great sound and build quality. These feel very high-end. Noise reduction is on par with other headphones I've tried. These are definitely on-ear, not over ear. You may need to take a break if your ears get uncomfortably smashed. I can bear it for hours though. While walking around the city, I've had the bluetooth connection drop out, but i'm not sure if that's an iPhone or headphone problem.
Title: Love these. Would give 5 stars if they were truly over-ear.

Review Contents: My biggest concern when I got these were that the ear pads would be too small. I don't have large ears or sensitive ears but those concerns were justified. The ear pads are pretty small. But they are also pretty soft which makes up for it for the most part. They get softer with use too. I wear these all day at work and the first week or 2 I had to take breaks because my ears and surrounding ... ear bones???... were getting sore. I even looked into getting replacement ear pads but of course, like more and more products these days they are proprietary sizing so finding a non Sennheiser brand replacement was futile.I love the sound of Sennheiser and the wireless range is crazy good with these cans. I put in some time and maybe my ear bones got firmer or I just got used to it, but now I can wear these all day without an issue.Anyway, I was worried about the size of the pads and while small, they're not unreasonably small.
Title: The ear pads are pretty small. But they are also pretty soft which ...

Review Contents: These are a great set of headphones for their purpose, so be careful not to judge them too harshly.What they do great at:- For the price, the noise cancelling is about 80% of the Bose (in my opinion). The padding is soft and forms a great seal and the noise reduction does what it says, considering the price. So a fantastic closed-back headphone with active noise cancelling and Bluetooth in a single package- Battery life- I like the dual cable & Bluetooth, so if the Bluetooth dies, you can still use the headphones- Voice calls are crystal clear, which is something considering where the mic is, and the headphones auto disconnect the noise cancelling when you're on a callWhat to look out for:- Sennheiser flatness of the mids as a closed-back headphone. It's unfair to judge them against my HD 598SEs (but I do anyway). Understand they'll sound flattish and has that typical closed-back sense, but that's why I have a pair of HD 598's when I want that clearer sound. I did feel they were a bit aggressively flat on the high notes versus just being natural- Yes, they've included Bluetooth controls, but they don't seem to be designed to be used all the time, as they're a bit fiddly. If you see the robust buttons on the Bose, you'd see what a more refined design is. I found myself frequently trying to figure out if I was touching the volume control or the next track rocker.- While the build is solid, I'm eyeing the headband with suspicion as I feel they could have made them a tad thicker considering they've hinged them to high heaven as part of how it compacts for travel. It hasn't broken yet, but if you look at a pair of headphones like the 598s, you'll feel like you need to treat these a lot more carefully- The soft carry bag. I suppose with all the money in electronics, you can't expect too much. I just feel I need to get an extra hard carry case if I'm lugging these around. And the bag doesn't do anything special for cable management, considering you have two cables to contend with now (USB and manual audio)It's terrible to call a headphone a good compromise, but that's what they are. A jack of all trades and a master of none, does make this a good value all rounder. I would recommend and buy them, if you understand their weaknesses and want them for their strengths.
Title: A jack of all trades and a master of none, but class-leading value at this price point

Review Contents: Price is low compared to other products in this category, but you can see why. Plastic feels cheap. It is very lightweight, which is good. Just feel as though it’s going to break before too long. I have hifiman and momentum 2.0 headphones, and these were the cheapest, and you can tell why. The cups are pretty small and can hurt your ears after a while. Bluetooth connectivity is wonky to get connected if connecting to multiple sources throughout the day. Sound quality, however, is very good, as you would expect from this brand. if You can
Title: which is good. Just feel as though it’s going to break ...

Review Contents: I bought these to replace a $60 pair of August EP650s which drove me crazy with signal dropouts while commuting and walking around bluetooth and wifi saturated SF. These are much better, but dropouts still occur. I would say they eliminate 80-90% of the problem. My old iPhone 6 may be part of the issue and who knows, more expensive phones might have the issue as well. This is my first pair of ANC phones so I have no comparison to offer, but they do a fantastic job on the subway. I can hear very little of the ambient environment, so I don't need to listen as loud which is more relaxing. Looking forward to trying them on a plane. Build and audio quality seem very good, except for the ridiculous tiny buttons which are hard to operate and distinguish from one another.  The "multifunction button" is the worst and has no tactile "click" when pausing/playing. Turning the NC off and on is harder than it should be. I also wish they came with a better case--they needn't have bothered with the cheap fabric one and I haven't been able to find an aftermarket one which fits. Overall, I will keep them but they definitely could benefit from a redesign of the controls.
Title: Good phones, poor controls

Review Contents: Very nice! Would definitely buy again.  Ear space is smaller than husband's Bose, but still comfy enough. Good sound and they pack nicely for travel.  Two things I would like - a better noise cancelling off/on. Right now, it's difficult to turn if on and there's no "announcement" to let you know it's on, unlike my husband's Bose which has a clear on/off position. Secondly, and this is true for all bluetooths, why not an app that connects so you can tell how much battery is left before it gets way down?  I had a list of requirements and these were the only ones somewhat reasonably priced that fit the bill.  Highly recommend.
Title: Very nice! Would definitely buy again

Review Contents: I own a pair of HD1’s. They cost almost 3 times what these cost. These are very nearly as good. Less detailed, but a warmer, smooth sound. Very comfortable and light. WAY better sound than Bose or Beats.
Title: These are very nearly as good. Less detailed

Review Contents: Bought these as a gift for my partner who works as an editor in medical publishing.The noise cancelling technology is odd and difficult to get used to. It is also difficult to detect initially, but  after wearing these for a few hours they are quite impressive. The NC tech in Sennheiser is very different from what is used in Bose and Sony, while I could detect the pressure it was not as overwhelming as the Sony and not as bad as the Bose either.It seemed as these also let a bit more sound in than the other two as well but these did well at covering up the softer murmuring of human voices in the background.  Possibly better than the Bose in that regard as none of this tech seemed to do well at eliminating directed human sounds.
Title: Give them a chance.

Review Contents: Previously had Senn Urbanite XL.Noticable differences in sound with the NC turned off:More neutral coloring than the XLs, wider sound stage. Clearer than I remember the XLs being. Bass can be underwhelming at times (I tend towards more bass heavy though).With NC tuned on:Sound lacks depth of bass, almost like the mids (especially high mids) are boosted. Same problem on all devices.Ultimately, the Modern Portable HiFi Elite Super66 are a good Bluetooth headphone for the money, and you won't be as disappointed as with these Sennheisers. Review Contents: With two little kids at home, I don't get to listen to my favorite music or movies on my home theater system very often so instead, I most often use headphones. For the past year or so I've been using a pair of Sony MDRXB650BT/B Bluetooth Headphones to listen to my favorite Spotify tracks from my smartphone at home or when traveling.I've used the Sennheiser HD4.50 BT Headphones in similar fashion for the better part of a month and have really come to like this pair of headphones for overall sound fidelity, comfort, and features.►Smartphone Pairing & Setup:The HD4.50 supports NFC so pairing the headphones with a smart device is incredibly simple. The only thing you need to do is make sure NFC is enabled on your device, turn on the headphones, and hold your device up to the left earpiece (it has the NFC logo on it). Pairing takes a few short seconds and that's it! Next time you turn on the headphones in range of your device they'll pair automatically. Pretty standard stuff but it's nice that it works perfectly every time.►CapTune:The next logical step after the HD4.50's are paired to your device is to head over the Play or iTunes store and download Sennheiser's CapTune app. This app is specifically designed to work with the HD4.50 headphones (and some other Sennheiser models too) and really to get the most out of the headphones you'll need the application. CapTune allows you to set all sorts of settings with the HD4.50 headphones including preset and custom EQ settings, bass and treble adjustments. There's a built-in music player within CapTune as well for playing back media.►Features:The HD4.50's have all of the features you'd expect from headphones in this class - Bluetooth, voice guided functions, built-in rechargeable Lithium-ion battery, and so forth. The product page and spec sheet are loaded with information about the features of the HD4.50's but one of my favorite features has to be the easy to use track controls integrated directly onto the headphones. This probably seems like a silly thing but it's nice not having to dig out my smartphone every time I want to skip to the next track. The headphones fold up nicely making them easy to bring along on trips thanks to the space-saving design.Although all of my music playback with the HD4.50's has been wireless it's important to note that you can also listen to music wired via a 3.5mm male-male cable (included).►Usage Impressions:I'm a fan of these headphones and music playback is noticeably better than my Sony XB650's with a fuller and more realistic audio playback. I took the HD4.50's on a short business trip and confirmed the noise canceling features are every bit as welcome as I imagined traveling during a busy workweek.The one area I did have concern is the earcup design. Sennheiser lists these as "around ear" on the product page and I interpreted that to mean an over the ear design (vice on the ear design) where the earcup materials don't press directly on the ears. That is not the case. With the HD4.50's the earcup materials definitely fit right on top of your ear. Thankfully the materials are soft enough and the pressure from the headset gentle enough that I didn't get a headache or discomfort to my ears even after multiple hours of consecutive use.►In the Box:- HD4.50 headset- 3.5mm auxiliary cable (1.4m)- USB-A to micro-USB cable- Black, zip top carrying case►Closing:Sennheiser is known for producing excellent headphones and the HD4.50 does not disappoint. This is a feature packed, well-built pair of headphones packed with all the technology bells and whistles while till delivering simple, quality audio playback. Comfortable, reliable, a solid pair of headphones. Recommended!

ABSOFERKINLUTELY!Now for the rest:If you're thinking these are going to be some magical sounding headphones that will beat your wired headphones, don't buy wireless. Taking into consideration you are literally streaming digital-to-analog data over bluetooth (NOT WiFi people!), if you keep your expectations realistic then you'll be stoked with the sound and quality of these.Comparing to HD 380 Pro Headphones:The ear cups are much smaller than that of other Sennheiser 380s so keep this in mind. It doesn't bother me because I like the smaller footprint for when I need to hit up Costco. The 380s are much bulkier which is good for studio, bad for mobility on the road. The sound quality of the 380s is better (richer bass for sure) - there's no argument there - however the HD 4.50 headphones are very comparable and if you attach the cable. The 380s have better mid to lows, but it's only slightly when comparing both as wired headphones.I've never owned a pair of noise cancelling headphones so I can't compare BUT this is definitely one reason I kept these. Usually I'm tuning to EDM music at work, but when I changed to classical, WHOAH, what a difference in ambient noise! The lows are almost completely removed from the environment around me. If you have "white noise" at work, this is a Godsend because it will almost eliminate that humming noise of a/c and fans etc. People talking is much quieter too so I'm going with the other professional reviews in that the noise cancellation is stellar. One thing to note after using them in loud environments like driving in a car, the cancellation might give you a headache; the extra noise cancellation messes with your hearing, but this is the same with all headphones and you can turn it off easily.Overall I'm happy with the purchase. Just don't be thinking these are going to give you studio quality sound like I did originally. They're still only $200 and I think they're great at that price point. Even if they are made in ch*na.
Title: Could they be better? Yes

Review Contents: For a long time I used a pair of Beats Solo2 Wireless headphones I bought for $200, and there are some notable differences between those headphones and this pair of Sennheisers.The Beats are designed for intuitiveness, aesthetic, and simplicity. They have three "buttons" - volume up, volume down, and the multifunction "b" button. They are very easy to use out of the box and look great, although the sound is built for bass heavy music. However, the tradeoff of the three button interface was always needing to have my phone out to deal with tasks like answering calls or using Siri.This pair of Sennheiser HD 4.50s on the other hand, is built for function and unbiased sound. The controls are intuitive according to Sennheiser, but in my experience there is a bit of a learning curve, and unfortunately the instructions that come with the headphones only have pictures but no written instructions. After I got used to the controls though, it was a great listening experience. The Sennheiser HD 4.50s are very true to sound, and the Active Noise Cancelling feature comes in very handy in NYC public transit. The 25 hour battery life is also great for commuters like me - I have used the headphones pretty regularly since I got them two days ago and they haven't died yet. In terms of comfort, the Sennheisers are a bit uncomfortable during the first couple hours of use, but fine after they're broken in.Summary:  At $149, the Sennheiser HD 4.50 is by far the best bang for your buck for ANC headphones. I recommend this pair of headphones for commuters who want great sound on a budget. If your budget is higher, consider investing the extra $150 on a pair of Bose QC35s or Sennheiser PXC 550s - it will be much more useful in the long run.Pros:  looks great, affordable, ANC, pairs w/ multiple devices, long battery life,Cons:  not very intuitive, slightly awkward button placement

Review Contents: The product is extremely disappointing given the high price. First of all bluetooth pairing is very slow. The device did not show up on my phone until several tries. It is heavy and ear cups too tight. My ears get warmed up quickly. Not too bad for the winter. But I don't think it would be comfortable in warmer weather. For this price one probably can buy three bluetooth headphones that use the same chip technology and have similar quality of construction.---------Additional Note:You have to use the cable supplied by Sennheiser to connect to listening device if you want to listen in wired mode. Standard 3.5mm stereo wire does not work, because the slot on HD4.50 is not 3.5mm. On the other hand, don't even bother listening in wired mode. The sound quality is by far worse than wireless bluetooth mode. The sound is flat and low grade. It's really strange, since one usually expect better sound quality with wired connection.

Review Contents: I love these headphones. There were some issues - like the connecting wire can skew the sound and can be fixed by twisting the wire like you may need to do with an old, dying pair of headphones/earbuds, and/or pressing down on the "start" button for (3) seconds. That was rather disappointing to have to immediately deal with. Though, the headphones are rather comfortable - I have a big head, small ears, and wear glasses. However, I can see how people complain about the headphones hurt your head after some time of wearing it. I experienced that too - mainly because I have TMJ and the bottom of the headphones hit my cheek in a location where my TMJ can get irritated and cause a headache.The sound is great, good bass. The noise cancelling is fantastic too. Of course, nothing compares to Bose's Quiet Comfort 35, which really drowns everything out. BUT these are perfect for me - I don't drive and walk everywhere, so it's nice to be able to drown out most noise but still hear a little of something.Not really budget friendly, but they are definitely half the cost of Bose's Quiet Comfort 35, but the quality is like 85% of Bose's - so in conclusion, Sennheiser headphones are a fantastic deal!

They are comfortable for longer wear periods and I was able to use them for conference calls int he middle of the Detroit Airport and no one had any idea I was there. So if you want to eaves drop someone, point the right ear piece towards them and turn the music off. Over all, I'd say they were a good buy for the price.
